instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-4924A: What is 820-4924A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.BATLOW_L: What is BATLOW_L? This signal tells the system that the battery is low, when the signal is low. Anytime you see an “_L” after a signal, that means that the signal is present when it is a low voltage, typically 0 volts to 0.5 volts.

threads.title: 820-4924AMissing S4 rails & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi All,

Just wanted to see if I can get some assistance on a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> I'm working on. Charger I'm using is a 85W magsafe 2 (straight from the wall not through a bench PSU) bought and used on two 3437s I was trying to fix so that should not be the issue.

Board looks spotless zero signs of liquid damage or corrosion, or even blown components (besides <CAPACITOR>C7380</CAPACITOR> was cracked but not shorted rail was still present).

Below are the rails I've checked:
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.43V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.57
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> = 12.25V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 3.39V

Everything looked normal until I got to: 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER5V</SIGNAL> = 12.56v. Schematic says it should be 8.6v.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER3V3</SIGNAL> = Same as <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER5V</SIGNAL>.

I then checked: 
PM_SLP_S5_Lcompletely 0 no pulse
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> ditto
<SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> = 0V

Is <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> used in the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>? I read a article while researching why it would be missing that most macbooks do not use this rail hence it's disappearance is usually a non issue. That said I did find another post on here where they were also missing <SIGNAL>S5_L</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>S4_L</SIGNAL> & were requested to note the below rails: 

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> =  3.35V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 3.24V 
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 2.96V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.43V

They were also asked if they trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>  if  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> changes. 
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3.42 on normal state 0V after shorting <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>. I also checked if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>S5_L</SIGNAL> pulse when first connecting the magsafe with <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> triggered and it did not both stayed at 0V.

Is there a way to check if the SMC is OK? I'm starting to suspect the SMC but unfortunately I do not have any replacements. and no <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> donor boards. Are the 3437 or 00165 SMCs compatible?

Thanks for your assistance.

threads.title: 820-4924AMissing S4 rails & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"Everything looked normal until I got to: 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER5V</SIGNAL> = 12.56v. Schematic says it should be 8.6v.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER3V3</SIGNAL> = Same as <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER5V</SIGNAL>"
Did you check in schematic where these power rails come from?
Why would you expect 8.6V, if are connected directly to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (12.57V)?

Do you believe what you see and can confirm, or what someone else tells, even no confirmation on that?
Putin said he started an "military operation" into Ukraine.
We should think that is not war???

"<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 0V"
PCH will not start power on sequence until get high level there.
Try starting with both charger and battery connected; trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ON_OFF_L</SIGNAL> to start.

You forgot to check/post <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: 820-4924AMissing S4 rails & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Didn’t trace it back just saw the annotation and took its word for it. I’m struggling to find a decent PDF viewer, the one I’m currently using has a nice bug where if you zoom in it shoots down 5 pages so I normally zoom into a level I’m comfortable with and can read things, than just use the search to bounce around where I need to be hence why I didn’t notice what line it was tied to.
This only came with the board, is the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> battery compatible? I only have that battery and the battery from the 1598. Both are probably stone flat though.

threads.title: 820-4924AMissing S4 rails & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> has 8.5V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Do you think battery will be compatible?

What about the two missing RTC signals mentioned?

threads.title: 820-4924AMissing S4 rails & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Still need <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.
Is the charger ORIGINAL Apple Magsafe 2, 60/85W?
Try another one, just in case.

"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.57
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> = 12.25V"
Can you clarify this?
Is the same power rail...

threads.title: 820-4924AMissing S4 rails & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yup genuine magsafe 2 85W charger. I don't buy counterfeit chargers after seeing what it did to a customers Bose QC30s. Fake Chinese chargers melted the micro USB port and the plastic around the port. DC in board is a bit iffy though, waiting for my replacements to arrive so I have not tried another yet. I also do not have the cross flex/io board installed just magsafe. 

PM-<SIGNAL>BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is created by the PCH isn't it? 

Think that's because I checked PPBus first before doing anything else, than replaced that split cap I mentioned which is on the S5 computing line. Changed the cap than checked the rest of the rails which is why I'm guessing computing was lower, as PPBUS is now also 12.25v. Cap I replaced it with may of been faulty though it did not read shorted when I checked it before and after installation. 

Since missing PMSLP is usually dead PCH what resistances would you normally expect on a 2.7 8GB?
l7310 & L7320 I'm getting 9 ohm to ground on both.

threads.title: 820-4924AMissing S4 rails & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Looks like something on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is shorted. I removed <RESISTOR>R5400</RESISTOR> to isolate S5 isense from PPBUS and found diode mode of 0.06 where S5 isense is 0.4. Is it safe to run the board with that current sense resistor removed to do some voltage injection or should I reinstall it?

threads.title: 820-4924AMissing S4 rails & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I don't understand you.
Have 12.25V at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and short to ground at same time?
Please, post useful information.
